headline: Ceausescu Goes to Peking
lead_paragraph: VIENNA, May 31 (UPI)— President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania left for Peking today at the head of a Communist party and Government delega tion that will visit China, North Korea, North Vietnam and Mongolia, the official Rumanian press agency said.

headline: Washington Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 — President Nixon's basic speech for political occasions seems to be taking shape on this theme: Peace soon, then prosperity.
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: A.C.L.U. Notifying Protesters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 31 (UPI) —The American Civil Liberties Union undertook the chore to day of notifying 2,400 defend ants arrested in antiwar demon strations here early this month that the Government has dropped charges against them. The District of Columbia cor poration counsel's office said the charges were dropped be cause it did not have enough information to prosecute.

headline: ENEMY REPORTED TO CAPTURE SNOUL
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31 — North Vietnamese troops reportedly drove a South Vietnamese task force today from the Cambodian town of Snoul, which United States troops captured more than a year ago.

headline: Cambodians Willing To Discuss Peace With North Vietnam
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, May 31 (Reuters)—The Cambodian head of state, Cheng Heng, said today that his Government was willing to open discussions to end the war in Cambodia if the Vietcong and North Vietnamese withdrew all their troops.

headline: All but 13 of 570 P.O.W.'s Refuse to Return to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31—Only 13 of the 570 disabled prisoners offered re patriation have agreed to re turn to North Vietnam, officials said tonight.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: P.O.W.'S AN ISSUE IN KOREA WAR, TOO
lead_paragraph: The refusal of more than 500 North Vietnamese prisoners of war to go home to the North sounded a faint but familiar echo: this same issue of repa triation halted negotiations to ward an armistice in the Korean War for months in 1952 and 1953.

headline: Proposal Rejected in Paris
lead_paragraph: PARIS, May 31 (Reuters)— Representatives of the North Vietnamese and Vietcong dele gations to the peace talks re jected Mr. Cheng Heng's pro posal today as “nonsense” and expressed their support for the ousted Cambodian leader, Prince Norodom Sihanouk.

headline: G.I. Unit in Britain Assails Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: LONDON, May 31—A thou sand United States servicemen stationed in Britain announced their opposition to the Vietnam war today. It was the Iargest antiwar protest among Ameri can military personnel sta tioned here.

headline: Pullout Is Not Seen as Threat to G.I.'s in Field
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Scuti, Vietnam, May 31—The 70 per cent reduction in the number of American combat troops in Vietnam has left major United States bases and supply depots more vul nerable to attack but has not yet increased the danger to the ground troops still in the field, according to a survey of Amer ican field commanders.
author: JULIUS EPSTEIN Hoover Institution Stanford University Stanford, Calif., July 11, 1971

headline: Memorial Day Observed Traditionally and by Protests on War
lead_paragraph: Memorial Day. 1971. was ob served across the country yes terday in ceremonies that underscored division over the war in Vietnam and the 45,000 American combat deaths it has produced.
author: By Juan M. Vasquez

headline: Troop Strength in Vietnam Reduced by U.S. to 255,700
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam May 31 (AP) — The United States command announced to day that American troop strength in Vietnam was re duced another 3,600 men last week, bringing the total to 255,700. It is the lowest level in more than five years.

headline: MINNESOTA G.I. WINS A STAY OF WAR DUTY
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS, June 1—A 20‐ year‐old Minnesota soldier re ceived a brief respite from Viet nam duty today when Federal District Judge Earl Larson de layed a hearing on his conten tion that his orders were illegal because war had not been de clared.

headline: Army Studies Charges Of Killing of 24 Civilians
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) — The Army said today it was investigating charges that United States airborne troops killed 24 to 40 Vietnamese women and children on a beach near Bongson in Sep tember, 1968.

headline: Nixon, Drugs and the War
lead_paragraph: In his news conference last night, President Nixon said it was important to keep the problem of drug addiction among American troops in Vietnam in perspective. His Administration, he said, was concentrating on getting at the sources of drugs in the world, that it was going to prosecute the drug “pushers,” treat the drug “addicts” and try to inform the American public on the general problem of drug ad diction.
author: By James Reston

headline: Antiwar Veterans Are Labeled ‘Irresponsible’ by Rival Group
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1— Representatives of a new group called Vietnam Veterans for Just Peace said today that they were angered and dismayed by the “irresponsible” protests of a “relative handful” of antiwar veterans in the capital last April.

headline: PRESIDENT GIVES ‘HIGHEST PRIORITY’ TO DRUG PROBLEM
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1— President Nixon pledged to night to undertake a “na tional offensive” to counter the problem of drug addiction among young Americans, in cluding servicemen who have become addicted while in South Vietnam.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: BROTHER OF PREMIER IS OUSTED IN SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1—Informed sources said tonight that Tran Thien Khoi, brother of Premier Tran Thien Khiem, had been removed as chief of the National Customs Investigation Division.

headline: Notes on People
lead_paragraph: Hoping to be the first pilot to fly over the North Pole from Equator to Equator in a light plane, Sheila Scott flew off from London yester day in her Piper Aztec, first stop Nairobi.

headline: Marine's Plea Rejected In 5 Slayings in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)—The Supreme Court re jected today an appeal by a young marine convicted of slaying five Vietnamese civil ians near Hue in 1968.

headline: Saigon Denies Rout by Enemy at Snoul
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 2—The South Vietnamese task force that withdrew from the eastern Cambodian town of Snout on Monday is still inside Cam bodia, a Saigon spokesman said yesterday.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: Some Interludes for the Restless Dial‐Twister
lead_paragraph: A holiday weekend at the shore. Rain. The television set. The little box does pro vide occasional compensa tions, even if only in reruns of movies with deliciously insipid plots. There is some thing atrociously comforting in watching “Night and Day” for the 17th time, in marvel ing at tall, handsome Cary Grant playing the diminutive Cole Porter and at Alexis Smith doing her familiar com mercial for the Good Woman.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: Cambodians Report Battles
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 1 (AP) — Cambodian troops guarding the eastern ap proaches to Pnompenh reported today they had killed about 200 North Vietnamese or Viet cong attackers in all‐day bat tles in the marshes on the eastern bank of the Mekong River about 5 miles from the capital. The current fighting is for tiny patches of high ground that are above areas that are expected to be flooded soon by monsoon rains.

headline: U. S. Comments on Pullout
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) —Jerry W.Freidham, the Pen tagon spokesman, said today that the South Vietnamese had intended to withdraw some main combat units from Cam bodia with the onset of the rainy season. The withdrawal, he said, “appears from here to be orderly and according to their plan.”

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: BOSTON, June 1 (AP) — A Federal district judge dismissed today a suit by Massachusetts. challenging the ‐constitutional ity of the Indochina war, reject ing contentions that the Presi dent has usurped the warmak ing powers of Congress.

headline: Envoys Guests of Thieu At Army Fete in Forest
lead_paragraph: FIRE BASE HOABINH, South Vietnam, June 1— With monsoon rains batter ing the palm leaves atop the dining hall of this fire base, President Nguyen Van Thieu, the American Establishment and diplomats gathered here this afternoon for an anniver sary luncheon — South Viet nam's 21st Infantry Division was 12 years old.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: MAYDAY ARRESTS UPHELD BY NIXON
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1—In the sharpest news conference exchange since he assumed of fice, President Nixon praised tonight the behavior of District of Columbia police during the recent Mayday antiwar pro tests and said charges that con stitutional rights had been vio lated by the mass arrests were an “exaggeration.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Copter Crash Kills 7
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Wednesday, June 2 (AP)—The United States com‐ mand reported today the loss of two more Army helicopters and said one had crashed 24 miles northwest of Saigon, killing seven Americans aboard. It was one of the largest losses of life in a helicopter crash in recent months.

headline: Coordinator Is Named For G.I. Drug Program
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) — Everett G. Hopson, a retired Air Force colonel, was named by the Defense De partment today to coordinate its policies and programs for curbing drug abuse in the armed forces. Roger T. Kel ley, Assistant Secretary of De fense for Manpower and Re serve Affairs, who appointed Mr. Hopson, is expected to announce a program later this week for better identify ing and treating G.I. drug ad dicts returning from Vietnam.

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: WAR‐CRIMES FIGURE DESCRIBES ‘THREAT’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) —Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Her bert said today that a military investigator had tried unsuc cessfully to stop him from fil ing war‐crimes charges by threatening to accuse him of assault in an alleged massacre of civilians at Bongson, South Vietnam.

headline: SAIGON ASSEMBLY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3—The lower house of the South Vietnamese National Assembly today passed a controversial bill on presi dential election rules that could leave President Nguyen Van Thieu with no serious chal lenger in the election next October.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Light on Mayday
lead_paragraph: President Nixon did little in his news conference remarks on the arrest and prosecution of the Mayday demonstrators in Washington to clarify the difficult issues in that controversy.

headline: Deputy Waves Grenade
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2—The lower house of the Na tional Assembly was thrown into turmoil tonight when an anti‐Government deputy pulled a hand grenade from his pocket and threatened to blow himself up. He was protesting what the opposition viewed as an effort to push through a provision limiting the number of presiden tial candidates.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Calley: A View From Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—It should be noted that the horrible massacre at Mylai was first brought to light by the Americans themselves. It was de nounced by American G.I.'s back from Vietnam and it was brought before American and world public opinion by the American press. Without them, the Vietnamese—it is shameful and pain ful for us to admit it, with our poor means of communication and our re stricted free press—would never know of the Mylai massacre.
author: By Tran Tan Quoc

headline: U.S. Used Billions of Leaflets in Indochina War
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2—The United States Army has printed during the Vietnam war 6,245,200,000 propaganda leaflets for air drops in Indochina.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: LAWYERS TO LOBBY FOR ANTIWAR BILLS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2 — A group of prominent lawyers announced plans today to lobby in Congress next week for pas sage of legislation that would end American involvement in Vietnam by the end of the year.

headline: Many Said to Fear Reprisals
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP) — Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam confirmed today that only 13 sick or wounded prison ers of war were to be re patriated to North Vietnam on Friday. He said most of those who refused to go feared re prisals from the Communists.

headline: 10 Held for Picketing Store
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex., June 2 (AP) —Nine men and a girl, among them eight soldiers from Fort Hood, were held in the city jail today on charges arising from their picketing of a jewelry store last night. Dave Zeiger from the Oleo Strut, a down town coffeehouse frequented by youths and soldiers protest ing the Vietnam war, said those arrested had said the store's salesmen solicited cus tomers from among soldiers passing by by talking with them and “profiting from their homesickness” before inviting them in to buy.

headline: General, Ex‐Aide Accused Of Murdering Vietnamese
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2—The Army accused Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson today of murder ing six Vietnamese civilians and assaulting two others in the winter of 1968–69.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Abbie Hoffman Denies Riot Charges
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 2—Ab bie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, pleaded not guilty to day to charges stemming from the antiwar demonstrations here last month by the May day Tribes.

headline: Heavy U.S. Raids Reported Near Snoul
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3 (AP)—Re sponding to a South Vietnamese request, hundreds of United States bombers and helicopter gunships struckt at what were reported to be troops of three enemy divisions in eastern Cambodia yesterday.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Joseph W. Bishop Jr

headline: HANOI DENOUNCES SAIGON ON P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 2 (AP)—North Vietnam charged today that south Vietnam's offer to free Sick and wounded North Viet namese prisoners was a sham and denounced statements in Saigon that only 13 of 660 prisoners wanted to go home.

headline: Nixon Plans Agency On Drug Addiction
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3—Pres ident Nixon is planning a new Federal agency to direct ef forts to stem the tide of drug addiction among returning Viet nam veterans and in the gen eral public.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Senate to Get Modified Proposal for War Pullout in '71
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 3 — The legislative battle lines start ed to take shape in the Senate today on efforts to force a troop withdrawal from Vietnam by the end of the year and to require a 10 per cent cut in defense spending.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Pimen Assumes Throne Of Patriarch in Moscow
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 3 — With centuries‐old pomp and majes ty, Metropolitan Pimen of Kru titsy anad Kolomna was en throned today as the new Patriarch of the Russian Ortho dox Church.
author: By Bernard Gwertznian Special to The New York Times

headline: The Reluctant P.O.W.'s: Charges, Countercharges and U.S. Disappointment
lead_paragraph: GENEVA, June 3 — “Do you agree to being released in the North?”
author: By Thomas J. Hamilton Special to The New York Times

headline: Sweep Near the DMZ
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (AP)—The Saigon command announced today that 2,500 marines were conducting a sweep in the northwest corner of the country in an effort to smash a North Vietnamese troop build‐up.

headline: HANOI NOW SAYS IT WON'T ACCEPT RETURN OF P.O.W.'S
lead_paragraph: PARIS, June 3—North Viet nam announced today that it was canceling all arrangements to receive sick and wounded prisoners of war from the South on the ground that only 13 out of 570 originally announced would be transferred.
author: By Henry Giniger Special to The New York Times

headline: 13 Head for Rendezvous
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. UP SHUR, Off South Vietnam, Fri day, June 4—Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners of war headed back to their home land last night in the air conditioned hospital ward of this luxurious troop transport.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Realignment’ in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: Reports from the key Cambodian border town of Snout indicate that the South Vietnamese withdrawal, which has been described by Saigon army spokesmen as a “realignment” of forces, was more like a rout, similar in many respects to the recent precipitate South Viet naniese retreat from Laos.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Richard N. Gottfried

headline: Thieu May Be Unopposed in Wake of House Vote
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3—In the South Vietnam ese Presidential election of 1967, there were 11 candidates, and Nguyen Van Thieu won with only 35 per cent of the vote. In the election on Oct. 3, it appears, the President may have only one opponent, or may even run upopposed, under a bill passed today by the low er house of the South Vietnam ese National Assembly.
author: By Craig It Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: The Obligation of History
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — When Thucydides the Athenian described the twenty‐seven‐year war between Athens and Sparta at the end of the fifth century B.C., he declared that his work would be “a possession for all time.”
author: By A. Geoffrey Woodhead

headline: U.S. Losses Up in Week to 48 As Those of Saigon Drop to 452
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (Reuters)—The allied mili tary commands reported today that United States battlefield deaths increased last week while those of the South Viet namese decreased slightly. The estimated enemy toll, they said, dropped sharply.

headline: Baptists Criticize Delay on Bible Tract
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, June 3 — The Southern Baptist Convention— the largest Protestant denomi nation in America, with 11.6 million members — ended its three‐day annual meeting here today after stanchly upholding its traditional conservatism.
author: By George Dugan Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Michael Hamilton

headline: Job Outlook Is Bleak for Vietnam Veterans
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 4 —When Jim Pearson came home from Vietnam five years ago with several medals pinned to his paratrooper's tunic, he was in no great hurry to go to work.
author: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Laird Not Satisfied
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (Reu ters) — Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is stilt not saris field with attempts by the South Vietnamese Government to curb the flow of ?? American servicemen, the Pen tagon said today.

headline: House Panel Told About New Drugs To Combat Heroin
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) —Scientists told Congressional investigators today of a new group of drugs that they said might mark “an important medical breakthrough” toward solving the heroin problem in the United States and in South Vietnam.

headline: ENEMY'S SUPPLIES SEEM UNCHECKED
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4—Allied military intelli gence officers are paying close attention to the heavy mortar and rocket fire that the enemy has been using since the close of the South Vietnamese thrust against the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos in March.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 13 Downcast Prisoners, Spurned by Hanoi, Return to Danang
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 4—Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners, described as saddened and bewildered by the last‐minute refusal of Hanoi to take them back, returned here today after a 24‐hour sea journey to nowhere.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, June 4 — The contem porary critics of our society often speak of its “hyprocrisy.” It is a charge naturally resented by the so ciety's leaders, for with few excep tions they feel perfectly sincere in what they do.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Prisoners as Pawns
lead_paragraph: Hanoi's callous rejection of thirteen sick and wounded North Vietnamese prisoners of war represents the final breakdown of a major American‐South Vietnamese pris oner repatriation effort that never had much chance of success.

headline: Public Jobs for the Jobless
lead_paragraph: The Congressional bill to create public service jobs for the unemployed is a constructive response both to the immediate exigencies of the recession and to the long‐term needs of unskilled workers. With nearly five million persons out of work, including many recent veterans of Vietnam, the nation has a moral as well as an economic obligation to take effective action to offset the human consequences of a downswing in the business cycle. The bill, now passed in slightly different versions by both House and Senate, would be at least a modest help because it would subsidize state and local govern ments in hiring 150,000 workers to fill subprofessional jobs.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: The shantytowns that huddle close to the big American mili tary bases in Vietnam all have their “scag alleys” — the muddy lanes lined with corrugated iron and scrap‐wood huts where for $5 or so G.I.'s can buy enough heroin to keep at bay for day or so the irritations of military discipline, the boredom of rou tine jobs or the anxieties of com bat patrols at the tag end of an unpopular war.
author: —Tom Buckley

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: George McGovern

headline: Law
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—“I approve of what they did, and in the event that we have similar sit uations in the future, I hope that we can handle those sit uations as well as this was handled.”
author: —Fred J. Cook

headline: 61% in Poll Assert Entry Into the War Was U.S. ‘Mistake’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5—Six out of 10 Americans now think it was a mistake for the United States to become involved in the Vietnam War, the Gallup Poll reported today.

headline: BATTLES REPORTED IN KHESANH AREA
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam. Sun day, June 6 (AP) —North Viet namese rockets were reported to have struck the port city of Danang yesterday and heavy fighting was reported near Khesanh in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam.

headline: Minh Assails Saigon's New Electoral Law
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6 — Gen. Duong Van Minh, considered the leading political rival of President Nguyen Van Thieu in the October elections, today publicly criticized South Vietnam's new electoral law.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Opposition Deputy, Jailed in Delta, Back in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5—A prominent anti‐Gov ernment member of South Vietnam's lower house came out of jail this weekend after a brief and bizarre confrontation with authorities in his home district, with his own political fortunes greatly enhanced, and the Thieu Administration's rep utation embarrassingly tar nished.
author: By Craig R. Whitney  Special to The New York Times

headline: ANTIWAR ACTIVIST ASSISTS JOHNSON
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 —About a day after Doris H. Kearns, a bouncy, 5‐foot‐4 young woman from Long Island who teaches political science at Harvard, was picked as a White House Fellow under President Johnson four years ago, an article by her appeared in The New Republic under the head line “How to Remove L.B.J. in 1968.”
author: By Robert Reinhold Special to The New York Times

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam —Nothing symbolized the hopeless ness of the prisoner of war issue more than the view last Friday morning from the top deck of the U.S.S. Upshur, a comfortable troop transport sailing the South China Sea. The ship, carry ing 13 disabled North Vietnamese prisoners who wanted to go home, and a tug pulling a re modeled barge to transfer the captives to their countrymen were going around in circles.
author: —Alvin Shuster

headline: C. I. A. Identifies 21 Asian Opium Refineries
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5— United States intelligence agents have identified at least 21 opium refineries in the bor der area of Burma, Laos, and Thailand that provide a con stant flow of heroin to Ameri can troops in South Vietnam.
author: Julius Epstein Hoover Institution Stanford University Stanford, Calif., July 11, 1971

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: Warren S. Josephy's recent letter displays a failure to grasp basic prin ciples of the antiwar movement; “Viet namization” and, indeed, the entire Indochina policy of the current Ad ministration are based upon the prem ise that yellow Vietnamese lives are less valuable than overwhelmingly white American lives and, therefore, provide a ready substitute in the Asian carnage.

headline: The Vietnam Debate
lead_paragraph: Another serious setback for South Vietnamese forces and a fresh expression of Presidential determination to hang on in Indochina until the Saigon regime can defend itself lend weight to two carefully qualified moves in Congress this week designed to set a cutoff date for United States military action in Southeast Asia.

headline: After Vietnam— Another Witchhunt?
lead_paragraph: THE conviction and sentencing of an American soldier for the commission of war crimes has brought to a head a national crisis and a national debate that, in the period ahead, may well reach historic proportions. What is at stake is the survival of the United States as the representative of such virtues as jus tify the claim it makes to the alle giance of its citizens and the respect of the world. It is never easy, in the midst of a developing crisis, to see its historical significance, but we must nevertheless make the attempt.
author: By Louis J. Halle

headline: ACCUSED GENERAL GETS A PROMOTION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 5—The Army has promoted a brigadier general to major general while investigating alleged atrocities that occurred under his com mand in Vietnam In 1969.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Brother of Hanoi Aide Defects to the South
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5 (Reuters)—The brother of one of the North Vietnam top diplomats has defected to the South Vietnamese author ities and will be presented to the press here Monday, a Government spokesman an nounced today.

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Nguyen Van Thieu was elected President of South Vietnam in 1967 by only 35 per cent of the vote in an 11‐man race. A new election is scheduled for Oct. 3, and Mr. Thieu, according to Sai gon reports, would like to make sure his margin is greater this time. He may have the field all to himself.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was judged guilty of participating in war crimes, a broad element of the public hooted at the justice of an army that brought lieu tenants to the dock but wouldn't treat a general that way.
author: —Robert Sherrill

headline: VIETNAM VETERANS PLAN AN ‘INCURSION’
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS, June 6 (UPI) — The Vietnam Veterans Against the War announced today plans for “a limited incursion of Vietnam veterans into middle America” for July 3–5 at Kan sas City, Mo.

headline: McCloskey Begins to Organize for Primary Campaign in New Hampshire
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N. H., June 6— Paul N. McCloskey Jr., the Re publican Representative who for several months now has been challenging his party and his President on the Vietnam war, started organization building in New Hampshire this weekend, and for some people here it seemed that history was repeating itself.
author: By Bill Kovach Special to The New York Times

headline: Get‐the‐Generals
lead_paragraph: PINE BLUFF, Ark.—One of the re percussions of the Calley trial is a move to Get‐the‐Generals. Why punish a young lieutenant and let the brass go free?
author: By Paul Greenberg

headline: Saigon Reports 83 of Foe Slain; Clashes Continue Near Border
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. June 6—Sharp clashes between United States and South Viet namese forces and North Viet namese regulars continued to day around a Government base high above the main road be tween Khesanh and Quangtri, with a predawn enemy attack in which 83 Norh Vietnamese soldiers were killed, according to Government reports.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. GETS 3 YEARS IN DEATH OF MAJOR
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Monday, June 7 (AP)—A 25‐ year‐old Army enlisted man was sentenced today to three years imprisonment and a dis honorable discharge for killing one of his officers and trying to kill another.

headline: DRUGS REPORTED TIED TO VIETNAM PULLOUT
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 6 (UPI) — Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Connecti cut, said today that the high rate of heroin addiction among United States servicemen in Vietnam had prompted the Nix on Administration to seek a step‐up in its rate of troop withdrawals.

headline: Two Senators Assail U.S. on Laos War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 6—Sen ator Stuart Symington said to day that instead of the $52‐mil lion publicly acknowledged by the Administration, the United States was spending “hundreds of millions of dollars” in a clandestine war in northern Laos.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon's Electoral Law
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Copters Sink 11 Sampans
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Monday, June 7 (Reuters)— United States heli copters attacked two flotillas of Vietcong sampans at the mouth of the Mekong River yesterday, sinking 11 sampans and killing 22 Vietcong, a United States spokesman said.

headline: ‘SYNDROME’ FOUND IN RETURNED G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga.— —“Stogdill,” came the voice over the loudspeaker, “time to play pool.”
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Tactics Disputed in Fight to Win Release of P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 6—For two years, the Nixon Admin istration has been running a campaign of publicity, and per ?? to marshal American and world opinion behind it on the issue of American prison ers of war in Indochina.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: TV: Nuremberg's Relevance to the Vietnam War
lead_paragraph: Several years ago Bertrand Russell was one of the key organizers of an international tribunal to consider the ques tion of whether the United States was committing war crimes in Indochina. The gen eral reaotion was that Lord Russell was at best a senile fool, at worst a propagandis tic tool of Hanoi. That was several years ago.
author: By John J. O'Connor

headline: U.S. Troop Strength In Vietnam Cat by 4,800
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 7 (AP)—The United States command reported to day that American troop strength in South Vietnam had been reduced by 4,800 men last week. It also an nounced that six Marine Corps units totaling 1,240 men would return soon to the United States.

headline: Brother of Hanoi Official Explains Why He Defected to the South

lead_paragraph: 2. Recent U.S. military actions in Laos and North Vietnam demonstrated our intent to move toward our objectives. Our operations and progress in Laos constitute one step along the route. Our directness and rapidity of reaction, in bombing North Vietnamese installations and deploying U.S. combat forces to Southeast Asia were others. Each step played a part. Their effect was to in terrupt the continually improving Com munist posture, catch the imagination of the Southeast Asian peoples, provide some lift to morale, however temporary, and force CHICOM/DRV assessment or reassessment of U.S. intentions. But these were only steps along the way. What we have not done and must do is make plain to Hanoi and Peiping the cost of pursuing their current objectives and impeding ours. An essential element of our military action in this course is to proceed in the development of our physical readiness posture: deploying troops, ships, aircraft, and logistic re sources in a manner which accords a maximum freedom of action. This is the thrust we should continue to pursue, one which is intended to provide more than one feasible course for considera tion as the changed and changing South east Asian situation develops. lead_paragraph: I. Analysis of the present situation. The situation in South Vietnam is de teriorating. Even before the government sank into confusion last week, the course of the war in South Vietnam had been downward, with Viet Cong incidents in creasing in number and intensity and military actions becoming larger and more successful, and with less and less territory meaningfully under the control of the government. Successful ambushes had demonstrated an unwillingness of the population even in what were thought to be pacified areas to run the risk of informing on the Viet Cong. War weariness was apparent. The crisis of the end of August—especially since the competing forces have left the govern ment largely “faceless” and have dam aged the government's ability to manage the pacification program—promises to lead to further and more rapid deteriora tion. The objective of the United States is to reverse the present down ward trend. Failing that, the alternative objective is to emerge from the situa tion with as good an image as possible in US, allied and enemy eyes.

headline: Screen: Nicholson's 'Drive, He Said':Movie Marks Actor's Debut as Director Tale of College Athlete Opens at Tower East
lead_paragraph: "Drive, He Said," loosely adapted by Jeremy Larner and Jack Nicholson from Larner's 1964 Delta Prize novel, and directed by Nicholson (his directorial debut), comes close to being the sort of movie about the anxieties and dilemmas of the sixties that no one ever made in the sixties—which were constantly confused with the more innocent fifties. It is not a great film, but it is an often intelligent one, and it is so much better than all of the rest of the campus junk Hollywood has manufactured in the last couple of years that it can be indulged its sentimental conventions.Specifically, it's about a star college athlete, Hector Bloom, to whom basketball is what boxing is to Private Prewitt what playwriting maybe to Tennessee Williams and what risking an arm or a leg or a life probably is to Peter Gimbel. Like some forms of art, it is, simultaneously, a heightened response to the world, a mystical retreat from it, and a practical way of getting along in it.In the course of his senior year, Hector begins to feel, in his word, disconnected. The old game doesn't quite mean what it once did. He is more than a little surprised to find that he is in love with Olive, the professor's wife with whom he's been having an affair, and he is shocked when the joy of his discovery isn't shared by Olive, who is not so simply pregnant.Hector admires and envies the campus radicals, who are so committed to a cause that they can interrupt a basketball game for an anti-Vietnam demonstration, staged as guerrilla theater. He himself hasn't the faintest idea where he is going or why. When a pro ball club asks him to sign, he demands only that the club improve the quality of the frankfurters it sells to the public, and cut the price from 50c to a quarter.In fact, Hector is so disconnected—at least in terms of the character as written—that it comes as a major surprise, late in the film, to learn that he is a Greek major. This bit of information, which I assume is presented seriously, is as unsettling as learning that someone you thought you knew extremely well is, in reality, one-half of a pair of twins. It means that an important (or, at the least, a time-consuming) part of Hector's life has been kept secret.Also fairly secret is Hector's state of mind, though William Tepper, a tall, dark-haired young man who may or may not have studied the collected works of Dustin Hoffman, defines well enough Hector's individual attitudes of frustration, anger and what might be called romantic campus lassitude. A reading of Larner's novel fills in a lot of these gaps, but otherwise the novel might mislead the filmgoer into expecting satiric fantasy (which the movie never achieves), having to do with unnamed wars (not in Vietnam), with a lot of bizarre characters who might have been created by Waugh, and with middle-class American-Jewish intellectual and social life.One result of this secrecy—perhaps simplification is a better terms—is that most of the other characters in the film, just because they are the supporting characters in the film as well as in Hector's life, are more thoroughly and quickly defined, and thus more vivid and appealing than Hector. I especially liked Karen Black as the besieged Olive, a woman who once might have ben fated to be misunderstood and badly used by men, but who finally liberates herself; Robert Towne, as her husband, who would prefer to dry his beard with an electric comb than wory about cuckoldry; Bruce Dern, as the intensely clean-living coach, and Michael Margotta, who looks like a young Elisha Cook Jr., as Hector's radical roommate whose ultimate act of survival provides the film with its obligatory, if shopworn, irony.Most importantly, al of the film's characters, and all of the performances, are touched with the kind of unexpected sensibility and decency that are rare in most films of this genre. It's a quality that I associate with the performances Nicholson himself gave in both "Easy Rider" and "Five Easy Pieces." Nicholson not only is good with actors, but he also chooses to avoid most of the visual (and aural) clichés of the day, and when he does indulge himself—as in the fine basketballl sequences—they no longer seem clichés since the rhythm of the sport more or less demands the treatment. I wish I could report that Hector was as interesting as the film that surrounds him.
author: By Vincent Canby

headline: Newley's 'Summertree' Opens:Hume and Yafa Work Revisits the 40's Death of a Serviceman Fixes the Action
lead_paragraph: Anybody old enough can remember, and anybody not old enough may imagine, the mood of sentiment about the land and the ordinary people and the quality of tree-shaded life in middle-America that gripped the popular arts, and especially the movies, during and for a few years after World War II. The mood passes—for a good many reasons—by the early 1950's, but a certain nostalgia for it remains. That nostalgia has been felt in several movies recently—movies that mean to recreate the 1940's—and it now appears brought up to date in Anthony Newley's "Summertree," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters and which attempts indicting the barbarities of Vietnam in terms of decent emotional strategies developed to illustrate life on the home front 30 years ago.I never saw the successful Ron Cowen play upon which "Summertree" is based, but I gather there have been a lot of changes—mostly directed toward "relevance" and a slight juicing up of the action. There is a new character, a little black boy (Kirk Callaway), who speaks for separatism. And the girl friend (Brenda Vaccaro) is now a somewhat older woman who already has a husband—in Vietnam. But the boy (Michael Douglas) with each toss of his rugged head, each glance from his friendly eyes, bespeaks Young America. And the gruff dad (Jack Warden) who nervously loves his son and finally betrays him into war, and mom who cares and puts on the coffee — they are an older America that appropriately lives for the young. Barbara Bel Geddes plays mom, and one closed-mouth smile of hers is surely worth 350 apple pies cooling in the kitchen window.The central image of the summertree itself — a backyard retreat where the boy goes to dream his life into being—survives in rather ridiculous ways: especially in a bit of tinkly music, and a worm-eaten leaf pattern superimposed on the screen over his first night of lovemaking with the girl friend. And his death, which is in fact the reason for the drama, is there also, as a final bitter irony of the war that the movie, not too stupidly, admits wholly through the medium of the television screen."Summertree" is a bad movie, but its badness proceeds not from its intentions, which seem honorable, or from its stylistic analogies to past modes, which in different hands could have been interesting. The badness exists, rather, moment by moment, in the insufficiency of each acted scene, in the niggling insecurity of Newley's camera, in the improverishment of each evocation of a quality of life—from the boy's dull guitar playing, which is supposed to be great, to the father's love of hunting, which should recreate the landscape, but only signifies a thoughtless and cruel pastime.Nobody's performance quite works in "Summertree," but it is possible at least to respect Jack Warden's tense privacies and Michael Douglas's restraint in projecting a youthful goodwill without either petulance or excessive charm. Brenda Vaccaro is reasonable off-type casting, but she does not seem resourceful enough even to explore the limits of this small, appealingly pathetic role.
author: By Roger Greenspun

headline: Fair Vote in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: Even with the most scrupulous self‐restraint, the huge American military, diplomatic, intelligence and propa ganda establishment in Saigon could not help but be a looming presence in the background of the forthcoming Vietnamese national elections. headline: Schlesinger: Truth or Reputation?
lead_paragraph: In seeking to suppress the Vietnam documents, the United States Govern ment asserted that their continued pub lication in The New York Times would “cause irreparable injury to the de fense interests of the United States.” If this assertion were true, then the case against publication would have been strong indeed. The protection of military security constitutes an entirely proper limitation on the freedom of the press and on the “people's right to know.” When on Dec. 4, 1941, three days before Pearl Harbor, the Chicago Tribune published the secret Army war plans; When on June 7, 1942, dur ing the battle of Midway, a Chicago Tribune story revealed that we had broken the Japanese naval codes, these were disclosures that might well have caused irreparable injury to the de fense interests of the United States.

headline: The Screen: 'Glory Boy':Violence Is Outcome of Veterans' Return
lead_paragraph: Some movies, often the very greatest, are genuinely difficult. Some others, never the greatest, are merely obscure. It is in this second category, films that by their own confusions and inadequacies fail to make the kind of sense they so unclearly intend, that Edwin Sherin's "Glory Boy," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Forum theaters, belongs."Glory Boy" is yet another movie made not about, but under the shadow of, the Vietnam War. When its young hero (Michael Moriarty) returns home to his father's run-down farm north of San Francisco, he brings with him a stupid but relatively harmless Army buddy (William Devane) and a Regular Army sergeant (Mitchell Ryan) who is more or less waiting put his 30 days before re-enlisting.The sergeant is no friend, merely somebody picked up because his stern jaw, his medals and his military manner will please the old man. But behind his tough exterior seethes a soul of sulfuric acid, and after he has humiliated dad, knocked unconscious a hitchhiking college girl (Topo Swope) so as to rape her, and dynamited the fish in the trout stream, it becomes fairly obvious that he is a one-man social, moral and ecological disaster.Between the father (Arthur Kennedy) and the sergeant there is a certain equivalence, for the old man has in gentler ways ruined everything he has touched (so you shouldn't miss the point, he keeps praising the farm as a Garden of Eden) and he too represents the militarism of an age—the age of World War II. The film recognizes that the two wars are not equal—the father is fallen from sentimental ideals; the sergeant is pure evil force—but symbolically and, at last, literally, the two cancel each other out.I think this is the most significant action in "Glory Boy," though there are several others, and there is a whole household full of representative types—including the girl who, unaccountably, comes back to cook and clean and put flowers on the dining room table. But except for what fits together all too neatly, nothing seems to belong with anything else, and it all feels like watching a series of strung-together three-minute sketches. Sherin's direction stresses action in the middle distance not all that bad, but limiting and the multiplication of pregnant pauses — so that sometimes it looks as though the actors really are standing around wondering what to do next.Almost everybody figures out something reasonable in time—except for William Devane, who plays for a kind of instant insanity and ends up suggesting, say, Jerry Lewis as Macbeth. But the two principle kids, Michael Moriarty and Topo Swope, really are something special—appealing without courting appeal, sympathetic without the production of any unnecessary charm. Michael Moriarty particularly brings a rather intricate intelligence to an almost incomprehensible role. But both he and Miss Swope introduce a quality I should never have expected in this movie—a quality of articulate and active lucidity.
author: By Roger Greenspun
